data.title: Large Gem in a Small Spot
data.text: I pulled up expecting a sit down restaurant, but still wasn't disappointed when I tasted the food.  The Kalua Pork was fabulous.  Slow cooked and melt in your mouth.  The mini size was just enough and filled me up without making me feel stuffed. Definitely a place to visit.

data.title: Great place for quick and tasty meal
data.text: Have been to HG last three times in St George and foe a inexpensive,tasty and quick meal it can't be beat. The loco moco is great and the garlic chicken is perfect with just the right amount of bite

data.title: Best Hawaiian meal in St George
data.text: These are your and my next door neighbors, even if you live across town. Food is authentic and tasty, and the Namasu is heavenly. Go there one time and you feel like family every time you visit. Aloha!

data.title: VERY Lengthy Wait for Mediocre Food.
data.text:
We ordered right behind the couple we were eating out with, and they received their order in about 5 to ten minutes, but our food took well over 30 minutes. The most upsetting part about this is that SEVERAL groups behind us received their food well before we did. Our friends finished eating before we got our food.

We ordered two bowls: the Hawaiian (one of our friends who got their food in a timely manor ordered the same thing) and a Teriyaki Beef and Chicken. We asked where our food was twice only to be told things like, "Beef takes a long time to cook." This is a flat out lie. Just be honest with us.

When ordering our food, (this does NOT include the cashier) the cooks behind the counter had lots of time for roaming about, chatting,  and smacking each other with towels. 
Based on other reviews, the insanely long wait for food is a common occurance. 

In an attempt to be fair, the food is pretty inexpensive for the portion, but I found the meal to be just average.

data.title: Like Going Back to Hawaii
data.text:
When there are a bunch of Polynesians working in the restaurant it gives you high hopes for having a good, authentic Hawaiian dining experience, and they do it right.

The ultimate comfort food, in my opinion, is a good Hawaiian plate lunch. Some rice, Mac salad and some meat with gravy or sauce. That's what it's all about.

It's Ono grinds that broke da mouth.

Translation....it's really good food.

data.title: Was ok
data.text: Stopped in for a quick lunch. I had the Hawaiian plate. My husband had shredded pork on a bun with fries. It was very good. Nothing spectacular, but good.

data.title: Great Hawaiian Lunch Plates in St. George - who would have thought
data.text: My wife and I travel to Hawaii several times a year.. we have been trying to get Don and his family to open a Honolulu Grill there - we can't find the same quality of lunch plates anywhere on the islands - what a shame.. guess we will just have to stay home to get the best Hawaiian lunch plates!

data.title: Utah's best Polynesian Restaurant
data.text: I try not to miss this place when i visit St. George and it's great every time! I love the 3-meat plate with pork and chicken. They'll sauce up your rice if you ask and they have a vinegar-cucumber side that's as good as the meats (I think) and almost as good as their guava cake...

data.title: Just like Hawaii!
data.text: Stopped into the Honolulu Grill tonight, and as usual, I wasn't disappointed.  The restaurant isn't fancy -- it's exactly what you will see on the Islands.  Friendly service, reasonable prices, and good Hawaiian food.

data.title: Wonderful food
data.text:
I love the cucumber salad & chicken, also that they offer two sizes of meals.  The smaller size is just right for me.  I've been there many times & have loved each meal!
Customer service is great, they always have a smile for you!!

data.title: oh so ono
data.text: really delicious food at a fair price.  nothing fancy, but really yummy. can't wait to go back and try more things on the menu.

data.title: Large Helpings, Good Food, Reasonable Price
data.text:
We were back at St. George this past weekend for landscape photography. Our day ended early after having to do some hard hikes in the Hilldale area.  My daughter had insisted we eat at Honolulu Grill after her officemate had suggested it.

It took us longer to get there since the Garmin GPS directed us to go to a non existent restaurant location.  Thank God for the iPhone Map ap, we finally found the restaurant. It is located sort of in a residential neighborhood.  In the same plaza was a Mexican restaurant with the aroma of sizzling meats filled the parking lot air!

Honolulu Grill reminded me of Hawaiian Ono in the LA area.  Same style of food, just bigger helpings.  It took me sometime to navigate through their different menu items. Except for a large group, composed of men and women in their late teens or early 20s, everyone else was much older.  I really felt uneasy in that everyone else inside the joint (except for the 3 of us) had tattoos, piercings and colored hair!

On to the food review.  I ordered chicken katsu combination, my daughter had the sesame chicken and my son had the Hawaiian plate.  The food was really, really good. My chicken katsu was cooked just right, not overly fried.  Likewise the sesame chicken and the Hawaiian plate were also very good.  Portions were larger than normal and we were stuffed after dinner.

I am sure we will be back.

data.title: Great food and large portions
data.text: I stopped there Saturday night just a half hour before they were closing.  I ordered Teriyki Chicken and Kalua Pork plate lunch.  It was too much to eat all at once.  I took the remainder home and had it the next day.  There was 2 large scoops of brown rice and a cucumber salad.  Everything was delicious.

data.title: Loved this place!
data.text: Great restaurant.  Portions are big enough to share - the mini is just right for a single person.  Large variety of traditional hawaiian fair.  We got the Kalu pork (which we loved), the teriayaki beef (awesome! - ask for sauce on the side!), a hamburger with an egg on it (I forgot the name, but it was really good!), a LauLau and masuri for our kids to experience some traditional Hawaiian fair.  The Laulau was good, but too different for the kids.  However, the masuri was a total hit!  And it cost less than $2.  Overall the damage was just under $30.

data.title: This place is ONO!
data.text: My wife and I are headed to Kauai in three weeks and we had to get our Hawaiian fix today.  This place is so great, the BBQ chicken is so delicious.  Make sure you stop here.

data.title: Good authentic taste - 3 families liked it
data.text: Liked the kalua pork, curry chicken, Honolulu burger, and Hawaiian plate lunch... Don't expect goodness to be fast.

data.title: Food was good, plentiful and pricey but service was slow.
data.text: Like so many locations locally, one person takes all orders, asks several questions for each item and collects money. They take your name and when food is ready another person emerges from kitchen, calls your name and delivers your food. We got there just before the rush of students and other customers and were half way through eating our food before the last person in line when we placed our order was able to place his order. Food was good but I ordered a  beef teriyaki single which came with with 2 scoops of rice and a scoop of mediocre macaroni salad. Wife ordered mini teriyaki chicken which had one scoop of rice and cucumber salad. Cucumber salad was excellent and her portions were better suited to our lunch appetites. Chicken was a boneless thigh and was moist and tender while beef was the thickness of sliced baloney thus making it appear tender. Single meal was $9.50 and mini was $5.50. As happens so often with me, I should have let my wife order and then said "me too". We will go back but we will also avoid going at 12:05 P.M. and getting stuck in the long waiting line to order our food.

data.title: Good
data.text: Food was good Mongolian BBQ is very Good. Great Katsu. Glad it was recommended to us. I thought it would be fast food type place.However, Service was a little slow.

data.title: Okay, this is truly a gem...
data.text: Who would have expected great Hawaiian food in Utah?  Not me.  But that is exactly what we found when someone recommended this "hole in the wall" to us when we stopped at the Tourist Guide Office.  We had two "mixed plates" and everything was good.  We noticed that folks kept coming in both to eat "in", and to "take out" all the while that we were there.  The service folks were really friendly, as well.  We enjoyed the whole experience.

data.title: Not fancy but good
data.text: Get the platter.  You could even share it - it certainly is enough food.  Great teriyaki, kahlua pork, and barbecue chicken.  Order malasadas. Best we've had since we were on Oahu.
